newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Chase Manhattan takes HK$.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Chase Manhattan takes HK$.

text.p: Asian debt markets offered a few new issues on Thursday.
Chase Manhattan Asia said it had chosen lead managers and market makers for the HK$1.5 billion three-year floating rate certificates of deposit issue for Chase Manhattan Bank Hong Kong Branch.
Chase Manhattan Asia is the sole arranger and bookrunner of the transaction.
Lead managers and bookrunners are Chase Manhattan Asia, HSBC Markets, Sakura Finance Asia, Schroders Asia and Union Bank of Switzerland.
The FRCDs will carry a coupon of 27.5 basis points over the one-month Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate.
Application will be made to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority to accept the certificates as eligible for its Liquidity Adjustment Facility, or discount window.
Chase didn't reveal fees, but bankers said the issue is expected to pay an all-in return "in the low 30s."
Bankers said that spread would be a bit narrower than those offered by outstanding LAF paper.
Still, some syndicate managers said they expected the deal to go well, given the good name of the issuer and the popularity of LAF paper.

International Bank of Asia launched its HK$500 million FRCD, seemingly timing the launch to coincide with the announcement that the bank had received a first-time rating from Standard and Poor's Corp.
S&P assigned the FRCDs a rating of BBB. It also gave the bank a long-term counterparty rating of BBB and a short-term counterparty rating of A3.
The FRCDs pay an all-in return of 79 basis points, a level bankers thought was reasonable for a BBB-rated bank.
International Bank of Asia last week said it would raise HK$495 million via a share issue.

Elsewhere, Indonesia's Bank Danamon launched a US$100 million floating rate note issue via Merrill Lynch International. The notes have a final maturity of five years but can be put on the third anniversary.
The notes were launched and re-offered at par to float at 90 basis points over the London Interbank Offered Rate.
With fees, the all-in return to the put is 100 basis points.
Some bankers said the issue compared favorably with the three-year FRCD for Bank Bali, another Indonesian private bank. That deal paid an all-in of 92.5 basis points.
Bank Danamon is rated Ba2 by Moody's Investors Services. Bank Bali is unrated.
In other news, Philippine Central Bank governor Gabriel Singson said he was considering a proposal to issue a 30-year bond in the international market.
The Philippines in September launched a 20-year bond in exchange for Brady bonds.
